required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Incidence and the Risk Factors of Nephrocalcinosis in Very Preterm Infants
clinical_study.official_title: The Incidence and the Risk Factors of Nephrocalcinosis in Very Preterm Infants at the Neonatology Centre of Vilnius University Hospital Santaros Klinikos

brief_summary.textblock: The study aims to assess the incidence and the risk factors of nephrocalcinosis in very preterm infants using patient data collected during hospitalisation at the Neonatology Centre.

detailed_description.textblock:
Nephrocalcinosis in preterm infants develops as a result of imbalance between the factors promoting or inhibiting formation of kidney stones. It is caused by intensive treatment as well as functional and morphological kidney immaturity. There is a correlation between the prevalence of nephrocalcinosis and low gestational age.
The study aims prospectively to assess the incidence and the risk factors of nephrocalcinosis in very preterm infants less than 32 weeks of gestation.

primary_outcome.measure: The incidence of nephrocalcinosis in very preterm infants less than 32 weeks of gestation
primary_outcome.description: Kidney ultrasound results will divide preterm infants in the group with and without nephrocalcinosis (control).

secondary_outcome.measure: Compare demographic, clinical, biochemical and treatment results between nephrocalcinosis and the control (without nephrocalcinosis) groups.
secondary_outcome.description: Patients data (demographic, clinical, biochemical and treatment results) collected during hospitalisation at the Neonatology Centre will be compared between nephrocalcinosis and control group.

secondary_outcome.measure: To evaluate the dynamics of nephrocalcinosis at 6 and 12 months of corrected age.
secondary_outcome.description: Nephrologist consultation of the infants with nephrocalcinosis at 6 and 12 months of corrected age

study_pop.textblock: The study population is a group of very preterm infants less than 32 weeks of gestation during hospitalisation at the Neonatology Centre.
